ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Econometric models (primarily OLS) and R code to generate them
I also really appreciated our review of notable studies to see these models applied in practice
Econometrics
Theory of econometrics and many modern applications
Time series regression, fixed effects, difference in difference models
Learned various applications of econometric theory. Learned practical skills like different variations of OLS regression, as well as the theory surrounding them.
This course was a survey of econometric methods. We covered multivariate regression, instrumental variables, time series methods, fixed effects, etc.
Intermediate econometrics
I gained more confidence in econometric methods and in R that I hope will be useful in writing my senior thesis. The final project in this class was quite difficult for me but rewarding in the end.
I learned how to conduct econometrics analysis on data using R.

In this course, I learned all sorts of statistical economics methods for analyzing data, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. More broadly, I also learned how to conduct independent empirical research.
I learned a lot about econometrics and how to read an economics paper.

I think this course has set me up to be able to read/follow empirical work in the social sciences (which is why I took itI'm not an econ major, but I kept running into empirical work I didn't understand).
I received a much more in depth familiarity with statistics and econometrics. I also really learned to read econometric papers, which I had not fully gotten in ECON 117.
I learned a lot of theory and the material was interesting.
I learned about multivariate regression and its properties, and regression methods for empirical purposes like instrumental variable regression, regression discontinuity, and others.
Statistics and how to do causal inference.

The mechanisms behind multivariate regressions and its variations. This course provided a lot of information on the theoretical foundation to multiple regressions, but with less emphasis on how to apply which type of multiple regression in which circumstance.
How to conduct econometric analysis through OLS (and many variants of it) and make statistical statements about them (standard errors, confidence intervals, etc.).
Basics of regression across multiple data sets and conditions

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think every aspect of the class could be considered a strength, most notably, our learning as applied to a project written in the style of a real econometrics publication. One weakness I think was the inflexibility for late work. With all that happened this semester, plus religious holidays and unforeseen circumstances, I really think a deduction for late work would have been preferable to a complete ban. I understand that puts a burden on Daniel but perhaps a happy medium can be reached.

Strengths: Zero
Weaknesses: the professor
Strengths: Prof Altonji is a kind and compelling lecturer. It was a pleasure to learn from him. Daniel, our TA, was also fantastic. No major weaknesses, I wholeheartedly recommend.
Strengths: pretty interesting, DANIEL the best TA . Weaknesses: not a lot of practice exams for the midterm/final, psets are long

Where do I begin. This was the most disorganized, chaotic class I have taken at Yale. The lectures were practically useless, but the slides were no help either because they were so confusing. Problem sets were so poorly formatted that it was not clear when a question was being asked. Never in this course did I have a clear idea of what we were doing or what was expected of me. Rather, I simply cobbled together a bunch of formulas before the midterm and final and relied on stats stuff I had learned in other classes. For someone approaching econometrics for the first time, I don't see how you could possibly make sense of a rather rewarding discipline when it is so horribly presented.
The course is well organized.

I thought that this was a pretty brutal class -- difficult material and lots of work. At the end of the class, however, I did feel much more confident in my ability to identify and execute particular econometric strategies applied to real-world problems. It's a good class to take if you want to write a senior thesis. Professor Altonji and Daniel (our TF) also offered great advice throughout the semester about studying economics and learning more about econometrics.

Professor Altonji also presented STATA code in the slides, but we used exclusively R in our problem sets and project. Therefore, the STATA code wasn't very useful to me (or to most of the class). I think that future classes should be either ALL in R or ALL in STATA (or give more STATA instruction, even if there is an emphasis on R).
Weaknesses: the lectures were not recorded, material was extremely challenging, didn't always follow the textbook, extremely fast paced.
As a whole, I felt like the course was very well designed. The sequence of topics was logical and well taught. Professor Altonji was very professional and clearly passionate about what he taught.

A strength is that it definitely teaches you about econometrics. A weakness though is that the material is quite difficult and is not always communicated in the clearest manner. Sometimes, the problem sets did not seem immediately relevant to the material.

The materials for the class were really well designed. I think it might be helpful to work more problems in the second half of the courseI think there is some material that we covered conceptually but didn't really get our hands dirty with.

The course felt very disorganized. I think it could've been improved by more consistency in the format of the slides, less emphasis on examples and more emphasis on the theoretical concepts, and a slower pace. It often felt like material was being crammed in when I did not even have a firm grasp of the most basic concepts. More consistency with the due dates of the problem sets would have been better, also. Additionally, the final paper assignment maybe should have taken place over the semester, because it was essentially due the same week as the exam which made it difficult to focus enough on either assignment.
It was hard for me to be engaged. I learned mostly in section not lecture that was more engaging.

Strength: you learn a lot. 
Weakness: Oh my god this class was hard.

Professor Altonji should write on the board  when he reads off the slide, the class becomes a memorization game. If he wrote on the board, and worked through each equation with us, we could see how we arrive at certain conclusions and internalize them better, rather than memorizing the order of words on a slide.

Strengths: the professor's lectures are very concise and it is easy to review the content. The professor also sets the expectations clear, which is helpful when studying for exams. Moreover, I liked the fact that the professor introduced many empirical papers so that we know how each of the econometric methods are employed in practice. 
Weaknesses: None.

Strengths are how comprehensive it is in covering regression (as far as one can go without linear algebra) and Professor is great.

Weakness is that the course is a bit too theoretical and often hard to follow at some points with the different notation and concepts/proofs.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. It's less structured than ECON 117, so you have to be quite self-motivated to continue learning and asking questions. But, I feel that is appropriate for an upper-level course, and Professor Altonji brings an excellent background of labor econometric analysis to class.
Take it with anyone else
Absolutely! I learned a ton in this course. I am a much more confident researcher now and I'm very glad I took it.
Sort of. Only if you really want to write a thesis and don't care about the econ curve
Not unless you absolutely must take it.
Only if you are really into econometrics or plan to write a senior thesis. Otherwise, I wouldn't put yourself through it.
No.

I would recommend this course to other students, especially those who want to conduct empirical economics research. The course is well designed and Professor Altonji is clearly passionate about what he teaches.

Only if you absolutely must take it for the senior thesis. Otherwise, if you are thinking of taking it for fun, I would not recommend. It is a pretty difficult class with a fair amount of work, exams, and an empirical final paper on top of that.
Absolutely.

If you are not required to take it, I would strongly encourage you not to take the course. It felt very unorganized and I have left with a blob of knowledge rather than a clear systematic understanding of the material.
Additionally, the department's switch to R makes it more complicated because all our assignments were in R but our professor was totally unfamiliar with R and our teaching assistant was not very familiar with it either.
Only if you want to do an econ senior thesis.
Yes, I absolutely do! It is a very useful to have a second semester of econometrics. This class also gives you valuable exposure to real-world research and the methods and writing used in them.

Yes and no. If you like this stats, by all means take it. Very interesting and incredibly useful. If you suck at stats like me, do not take this class. It is very hard and prepare to spend most of your time in OH and on PSETs. It is not a requirement of the major (unless you are econ-cs).

If there is another course that offers a more practical education of multivariate regressions, take that course  this course is very theoretical, and will leave you feeling with a lot of knowledge on multivariate regressions but very little experience in applying them. If you do take this course, be prepared to learn from the textbook  you simply cannot learn from Professor Altonji alone.
Yes, especially with professor Altonji. The course is crucial if you want to do empirical work.
I would for the major requirement for thesis and also its use for other classes as an intro to R or STATA.
